headline.main: Many Americans Struggling to Pay Medical Bills

docs.abstract: Roughly a third of Americans are burdened by medical costs, a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention study finds.
docs.snippet: Roughly a third of Americans are burdened by medical costs, a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention study finds.

docs.lead_paragraph: Arguments over the health care law are set to begin next week, and the law’s supporters and adversaries have begun publicity pushes to highlight their stances.

headline.seo: Republicans Attack Health Law as Supreme Court Hearing Nears
headline.main: Publicity Push as Health Law’s Court Date Nears
headline.print_headline: Publicity Push as Health Law’s Court Date Nears

docs.abstract: Republicans have put together a highly coordinated two-week campaign against the health care law, seizing on the legislation’s second anniversary and the upcoming oral arguments before the Supreme Court concerning its constitutionality.
docs.snippet: Arguments over the health care law are set to begin next week, and the law’s supporters and adversaries have begun publicity pushes to highlight their stances.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Arnold S. Relman and Dr. Marcia Angell, both former editors of The New England Journal of Medicine, continue to advocate against the “commercial exploitation of medicine.”
docs.abstract: Profiles of Dr Arnold S Relman and Dr Marcia Angell, colleagues for decades and both former editors of The New England Journal of Medicine; also late-life romantic partners, the couple has long waged a joint crusade against for-profit medicine, especially its ancillary profit centers of commercial insurance and drug manufacture.
docs.snippet: Dr. Arnold S. Relman and Dr. Marcia Angell, both former editors of The New England Journal of Medicine, continue to advocate against the “commercial exploitation of medicine.”

docs.lead_paragraph: Both sides believe that a 70-year-old precedent involving the Constitution’s commerce clause supports their arguments.

headline.seo: At Center of Health Care Fight, Roscoe Filburn’s 1942 Case
headline.main: At Heart of Health Law Clash, a 1942 Case of a Farmer’s Wheat
headline.print_headline: At Heart of Health Law Clash, a 1942 Case of a Farmer’s Wheat

docs.abstract: Supporters and opponents of the health care law say decision in Wickard v Filburn, which recognized the power of the federal government to regulate economic activity, supports their arguments about the law's constitutionality; Obama administration says if the government can make farmers choose between growing crops on their own land and paying a penalty, it can surely tell people that they must obtain health insurance or pay a penalty; opponents say case set outer limit of federal power, one the health care law exceeds.
docs.snippet: Both sides believe that a 70-year-old precedent involving the Constitution’s commerce clause supports their arguments.

docs.lead_paragraph: Rick Santorum has been a prolific writer of articles, letters and columns, all displaying many of the traits that define him as a presidential candidate.

headline.seo: In Santorum Writings, a Consistently Conservative Voice
headline.main: Santorum Writings Voice Strikingly Consistent Views
headline.print_headline: Santorum Writings Voice Strikingly Consistent Views

docs.abstract: Rick Santorum has been a long-time prolific writer of op-ed articles, letters to the editor and guest columns in some of the country’s largest and most influential newspapers, all displaying many of the traits that define him as a presidential candidate: a deep and unwavering Catholic faith, a suspicion of secularism and a conviction that the country is on a path toward cultural ruin.
docs.snippet: Rick Santorum has been a prolific writer of articles, letters and columns, all displaying many of the traits that define him as a presidential candidate.

docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly three generations, women have been taught that annual Pap smears, mammograms and visits with their doctor were essential to good health. Now all that is changing. National guidelines are urging less frequent screening for breast and cervical cancer. The declining use of menopause hormones means that older women no longer need to check in with their doctors to obtain annual refills. Women are delaying childbirth, and some birth control methods are effective for five years, giving women even less incentive to schedule a regular appointment.

headline.main: The Annual Appointment Loses Some Relevance

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope Well column notes that many women are unsettled by shifting national guidelines urging less frequent screening for breast and cervical cancers; contends that while there is a scientific basis for the opinion that fewer tests will yield fewer false-positives, annual visits are still useful, enabling gynecologists to discuss important non-reproductive issues with their patients. Drawing (M)
